ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Timothy Terway
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Terway, Timothy
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim Terway

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  I can't praise Tim's work enough. His biggest strength was not only what and how he taught but how he encourages critical thinking and analysis. Also how he encourages students to incorporate experiences from outside the classroom and academic activities to the learning experience with exercises.
Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Very accessible, helpful guidance for papers

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  'Teaching assistant' doesn't really apply to Tim; he's a co-professor. He's probably the strongest lecturer I've encountered at Yale. I've benefited greatly from his teaching and feedback.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  Tim was an incredible teaching assistant. He is obviously brilliant but was always very responsive over email and open to meeting to discuss the final paper. He always provided very helpful insight and guidance and was instrumental in making this a great course.

Instructor: Timothy Michael Terway  -Tim was a huge part of this course. He is a gifted communicator & discussion-leader, as well as a thought-leader in the policy sciences.His effort to help prepare for each class and make sure that each class ran smoothly was clear.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Susan and Tim are amazing and this course was invaluable. I am so happy I was able to take it in my first semester of FES. They are both so open to getting together to discuss the course material and passionate about the subject. I was blown away by how much of their personal experience they contributed directly to the course and how invested they were. I am so grateful for their time and energy.

Though it was sometimes difficult to follow Susan's train of thought, it was a good challenge to keep up. I didn't mind not understanding immediately because it put the onus on me to do the readings and discover how to understand the topic myself.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: If you are accustomed to conventional natural resource policy/management courses, this course will revolutionise the way you think about environmental problems and just problems in general

This is the best course the school offers. while every class focuses on trying to prescribe solutions, this is the only course that leads to critically think about the problems and the right questions before prescribing solutions.
I definitely think I will be able to apply the framework we learned to my work in the future to give guidance in solving environmental problems.
This course improved my critical thinking and policy analysis skills, as well as my capacity for self-assessment.

The readings for this course were always phenomenal and I gained so much from them. I was also grateful for Tim and Susan bringing detailed examples of how they apply the theory we learn in their work to lecture.

-Susan and Tim worked to create a friendly, growth-oriented class environment. The class was very discussion-based. -I know that I will use the information from this class in every future job/position, and that it will help me to be a more effective leader in the environmental field.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I could use more examples throughout the course to practice the concepts of the framework. The activity where we highlighted articles looking for components of problem orientation was very useful to help understand how this can actually be applied. More exercises/mini case studies like this could really aid my understanding and comprehension of the framework.

I sometimes felt like I was sending my weekly journals into the void and not receiving response or feedback on my performance. I was always a little anxious about whether I was performing well in the course.
-It would be interesting to have a few guest speakers over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The group discussions outside of class were excellent to help talk through the components of the class.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The framework learned in this course should be a must have for everyone working in policy, as I am

This is one of the few classes at FES that is truly interdisciplinary and provides a structure for how to solve environmental problems. We need more classes like this in FES because that is what the MEM degree is all about.

This course is more 'foundational' than the actual foundations courses. It's more about how to think, rather than what to think. The analytical skills taught in this course complement and enhance the specialized, scientific and empirical approaches taught in other courses.
I am planning on pursuing the environmental policy analysis specialization and this course was a perfect foundation for future coursework.

This course was exactly the type of natural resource management approach I would like to pursue in my professional career. The skills and topics learned in this course, I'm sure, will be directly applicable wherever I go and for whatever I do.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn about how to effectively solve environmental problems.
I'd heard strong praise from alumni of the course (many of whom are prominent in the environmental field), and wanted more experience with noneconomic policy analysis.

I struggle with how to truly approach environmental issues in an interdisciplinary way and learning the policy sciences framework was incredibly helpful to me in understanding how to synthesize information from various disciplines together.
It was suggested to me by many people as being one of the best courses at FES.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
More than exceeded my expectations. I encourage everyone to take this class
Yes
I didn't know quit what to expect, but my expectations were high based on what alumni have said. The course exceeded these expectations.
-This course exceeded my expectations.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Ability to discuss readings and coursework among peers.

the framework presented in the course is useful in every aspect of life, not only for academic or professional activities and the weekly group meetings/discussions were a good experience to share every day experiences with this framework in mind.

I unfortunately did not have a great experience with my group and as a result did not get as much as I'd hoped out of the course. We had a group of three and one member simply refused to show up. I became frustrated with needing to corral everyone and honestly gave up towards the end of the semester. However, when I met with other groups, it was a fantastic opportunity to learn how they were processing the theory-heavy material in the course and I always appreciated the discussion.
Because Susan is not always the easiest to follow in class, we had self-organized group meetings once a week. They were extremely helpful in moving us forward, as a group, with the class material.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take this course if you to learn how to truly think about problems in an integrated, interdisciplinary way.

This is a great course to help provide a a methodology to solve environmental problems that can be applied in a multitude of different ways. This class can get a little heady/philosophical which can be hard to understand at points but the class is definitely worth it.
Take it

Meet with Tim and Susan early and often. I left writing my final paper too late and had a very tough time pulling it together. Tim and Susan were incredibly helpful throughout the semester as I digested my research and applied the policy sciences to a concrete case. They are also generally open to discussing your other coursework and trajectory at FES. I was so grateful for how generous they both were with their time.

Take it, even if you don't like theoretical studies at first. The beginning few weeks are harder to follow than the rest, but stick with the readings and absorb as much as you can from the theory so when the practical knowledge starts in the second half, you'll hit the ground running. It was my favorite course this semester.
